content: Legislation to rewrite and reauthorize the Export Administration Act of 1979 (EAA) may be considered in the 111th Congress. In the 110th Congress, various bills were introduced addressing penalties, enforcement, diversion of goods, and integration of export control data. The EAA controls sensitive dual-use goods with civilian and military applications, including items that can contribute to the proliferation of nuclear, biological, and chemical weaponry. The Export Administration Act of 1979 (EAA) controls sensitive dual-use goods with civilian and military applications, including items that can contribute to the proliferation of nuclear, biological, and chemical weaponry. The EAA is the statutory authority for the Export Administration Regulations (EAR), which are administered by the Bureau of Industry and Security (BIS) located in the Department of Commerce. The Export Administration Act of 1979 (EAA) regulates exports of dual-use items with military applications. Export controls are based on strategic relationships, threats to national security, and international business practices. Some stakeholders advocate for liberalizing export regulations to benefit American companies. The Export Administration Act of 1979 regulates exports of dual-use items with military applications. There is a need to liberalize U.S. export regulations to allow American companies to compete internationally for high-technology goods. Some argue that export controls should be tightened to address national security threats. The report discusses the evolution of the Export Administration Act, types of controls authorized, Commerce Control List, export licensing procedures, and issues related to maintaining export controls under IEEPA. Export controls have been a part of U.S. policy for almost a century, with the end of WWII marking a new era in export control policy. The discussion covers various controlled commodities, competing business and national security perspectives, and key themes in the export control debate. The end of WWII marked a new era in export control policy, with a focus on the Soviet-Bloc countries during the Cold War. The Export Control Act of 1949 recognized the security threat and established a peacetime export control system with three reasons for imposing controls: short-supply, national economic impact, and foreign policy promotion. The President used foreign policy controls to promote US interests, including regional stability, human rights, anti-terrorism, and non-proliferation. National security controls restricted exports that could enhance military capabilities of threatening countries. A multilateral export control regime was established with NATO allies post-WWII. The establishment of a multilateral control regime with NATO allies led to the creation of the Coordinating Committee for Multilateral Export Controls (CoCom) in 1949. CoCom controls reflected a high level of restrictions, and the Export Control Act was renewed multiple times without significant changes. In the late 1960s, the U.S. export control system was revised with the passage of the Export Administration Act of 1969, replacing the restrictive Export Control Act of 1949. Subsequent amendments in 1974, 1977, and a comprehensive rewrite in 1979 continued the trend towards less restrictive export controls. The Export Administration Act of 1969 was revised in 1979 and amended in 1985. The collapse of the Soviet Union in 1989 led to some changes in U.S. export control policy. Despite some streamlining, the basic structure of the law remains intact. There are calls for a revamp to enhance exports or focus on current national security threats. The dissolution of CoCom in 1994 and its replacement by the Wassenaar Arrangement in 1997 significantly changed the export control environment, raising questions about the effectiveness of U.S. export controls in achieving national security objectives and the fairness of unilateral controls to American industry. Congress has not reached an agreement on this issue. The Export Administration Act has not been reformed since the 101st Congress, with export controls being extended through temporary measures and Executive Orders. There are debates on whether to liberalize or tighten controls under the International Emergency Economic Powers Act, with concerns about constraints on the export control process. Operating under IEEPA imposes constraints on the export control process, making it vulnerable to legal challenges. Legislation has temporarily extended the EAA of 1979, removing the need for IEEPA powers. Export control authority currently operates under Executive Order 13222. President Obama initiated a review of the U.S. export control system, with Defense Secretary Gates outlining key reform elements in 2010. Defense Secretary Gates proposed a 4-pronged approach to reform the export control system in 2010, aiming to create a single licensing agency, adopt a unified control list, establish an integrated IT system, and set up a single enforcement coordination agency. The changes were planned to be implemented in three phases, with the final phase requiring legislative action. The reform of the export control system proposed by Defense Secretary Gates in 2010 aimed to harmonize the Commerce Control List (CCL) with the U.S. Munitions List (USML) in three phases, with the final phase requiring legislative action. The first phase involved preparatory work to establish a tiered control structure, standardized licensing processes, an "Enforcement Fusion Center," and a single electronic gateway. Phase II would implement a harmonized licensing system with two identically structured tiered control lists. The White House fact sheet proposes harmonization and tiering of control lists to reduce license requirements. It includes moving items from munitions list to dual-use list, examining unilateral controls, and consulting with partners on multilateral controls. A new export control system with a single licensing agency would debut in Phase III. The 3-phase plan proposed merging harmonized control lists, establishing a Primary Enforcement Coordination Agency, and implementing a single IT system for licensing and enforcement. Secretary Gates predicted the plan would unfold over the next year, but many questions remain unanswered, especially regarding legislative actions needed for certain proposals. The Phase II of the plan involves potential changes to the structure of control lists, requiring legislative consent and multilateral consultations. The placement of the proposed licensing agency within existing departments or as an independent entity is still undecided, with differing opinions on each option.
